questions.question: What does it mean for two statements to be logically equivalent?
options: They have the same truth value in all possible cases
They have the same number of operators
questions.explanation: Two statements are logically equivalent if they have the same truth value in all possible cases. This is denoted by p ≡ q or p ⇔ q.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs are logically equivalent?
questions.explanation: The implication p → q is logically equivalent to ¬p ∨ q. This can be verified using truth tables or logical laws.

questions.question: What is De Morgan's first law?
questions.explanation: De Morgan's first law states that ¬(p ∧ q) ≡ ¬p ∨ ¬q. The negation of a conjunction is the disjunction of the negations.

questions.question: What is De Morgan's second law?
questions.explanation: De Morgan's second law states that ¬(p ∨ q) ≡ ¬p ∧ ¬q. The negation of a disjunction is the conjunction of the negations.

questions.question: Which statement is logically equivalent to the contrapositive of p → q?
questions.explanation: The contrapositive of p → q is ¬q → ¬p, and they are logically equivalent. If the original statement is true, the contrapositive is also true.

questions.question: Is the converse of an implication logically equivalent to the original implication?
questions.explanation: The converse (q → p) is NOT logically equivalent to the original implication (p → q). They can have different truth values.

questions.question: What is the double negation law?
questions.explanation: The double negation law states that ¬¬p ≡ p. Negating a proposition twice returns you to the original proposition.

questions.question: Which statement is logically equivalent to p ↔ q?
questions.explanation: The biconditional p ↔ q is logically equivalent to (p → q) ∧ (q → p). It means both implications must hold true.

questions.question: How can you prove two statements are logically equivalent?
options: Show their truth tables are identical
questions.explanation: Two statements are logically equivalent if their truth tables produce identical results for all possible input combinations. You can also use logical laws to transform one into the other.

questions.question: What symbol is commonly used to denote logical equivalence?
questions.explanation: Logical equivalence is denoted by ≡ or ⇔. When we write p ≡ q, it means p and q have the same truth value in all cases.
